awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  A D-band, silicon-based, phased array radar front-end module for smart sensing applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to develop a millimeter-wave imaging radar sensor with significant advantages over current radar products including a smaller form factor, lower manufacturing cost, less signal processing and integration complexity, and improved detection performance such as range and resolution. The proposed miniature imaging radar sensor supports versatile deployment and can be ubiquitously applied to a wide range of short- and medium-distance wireless sensing use cases including industrial safety monitoring, building security, patient surveillance in medical and healthcare facilities, etc. The proposed research seeks to aligns with the Federal Communications Commission's (FCC’s) recent plan to develop new technologies for the global radar sensor market. The proposed technology requires close collaboration between the startup and a university team, which will enhance industry/academia partnerships in the United States.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project seeks to study and demonstrate feasibility of a D-band, front-end phased array radar module design that enables an imaging radar sensor capable of operating beyond 100 GHz with a wide bandwidth. The radar module prototype under consideration consists of a scalable area-efficient front-end architecture, phased array transceiver circuits supported by a mass-producible silicon technology, and a low-cost antenna-in-package (AiP) compliant with standard manufacturing and assembly process. The proposed research includes detailed design analysis, modeling, and simulation verification of a front-end system and core circuit blocks. The project also includes antenna prototype designs and feasibility analysis for module-level integration.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Our STTR Phase-1 research and development are focused on designing a silicon-based phased array frontend module to enable a compact radar sensor operating at D-band. Commercial high-volume compatible RF-optimized CMOS technology, as well as novel Antenna-in-Package (AiP) technologies based on two different substrates are evaluated in depth in our feasibility study. This frontend module is a centerpiece of our D-band millimeter-wave (mmWave) radar sensor under development to drastically improve contactless sensing capabilities and support a wide range of applications including industrial, automotive, infrastructure, IoT, security, and healthcare use cases. Some application examples include safety and navigation for autonomous mobile robots, automotive in-cabin passenger/infant monitoring, and vital sign detection and sleep pattern monitoring, etc.

Our joint team from Astrabeam and the Pennsylvania State University have successfully completed three main technical tasks in Phase 1:

  1. System-level analysis including link budget, frontend architecture, and radar frontend specifications. Our RF frontend architecture supports phased array scalability to meet different range and angular resolution requirements.
  2. Key building block development of the proposed beamformer RFIC including power amplifier (PA), frequency multiplier, phase shifter, and mixer-first receiver. Based on the simulation and preliminary hardware measurement results, our RFIC designs are expected to achieve high transmitter power efficiency, accurate and calibration-free phase control, and highly linear and low-power receiver, all of which are critical for the proposed phased array radar module to operate at D-band.
  3. Antenna-in-package design and module integration with RFIC based on two different substrates. The startup has engaged multiple commercial vendors to access material and process information for our design analysis. Our simulation and modeling results in Phase 1 have successfully demonstrated the AiP design feasibility for both substrate technologies.

Our Phase 1 research activities have generated important intellectual properties related to RFIC and AiP technologies in our portfolio for commercialization, including conference/journal publications and patent filings. It is worth noting that the University team’s phase shifter paper also won the Best Student Paper Award (first place) at the 2023 IEEE RFIC Symposium. 


Last Modified: 02/28/2024
Modified by: Kevin X Gu
